Award.AwardTitle: Simulation of Chemical Processes in Solution using Hybrid Quantum and Molecular Mechanical Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Jiali Gao of the University of of Minnesota, Twin Cities is supported by an award from the Theory, Models and Computational Methods to develop an ab initio valence bond model based on a mixed molecular orbital and valence bond (MOVB) approach for the description of the adiabatic and diabatic potential energy surfaces. The PI and his research group make use of combined quantum mechanical and molecular mechanical (QM/MM) methods to carry out dynamics simulations. They are developing a hierarchy of QM/MM models based on ab initio valence bond theory for studying chemical reactions in condensed phases. They employ an ab initio self-consistent field valence bond theory to treat the quantum mechanical subsystem for use as a guide to formulate a well-defined, two-state MOVB model based on molecular orbital theory. Additionally they are developing an effective Hamiltonian MOVB method that can be conveniently calibrated and used by experimentalists to study chemical reactivity and dynamics in solution. Finally, they are extending the MOVB method into the realm of density functional theory

The focus of this research is to design computational methods to investigate chemical reactions in solution, particularly those systems where interactions with the solvent itself play a major role. These studies lead to a deeper understanding of solvent effects and chemical reactivity in condensed phases. The PI and his coworkers have implemented their methods in widely available software packages for use by non-theorists in many fields of biochemistry, chemistry, biophysics, engineering, catalysis and atmospheric science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop hybrid quantum mehcanical and molecular mechanical (QM/MM) methods to study chemical processes, especially those involving charge transfer reactions. To increase the accuracy and applicability, special emphasis was placed on valence bond based approaches for understanding the nature of intermolecular interactions. The methods were further extended to treat the entire macromolecular and condensed phase systems by quantum mechanical approaches based on molecular fragments. A novel multistate density functional theory (MSDFT) has been developed, which goes beyond the Kohn-Sham DFT approach by using multiple determinants to explicitly treat systems with strong correlations. The method also allows interaction energy decomposed into speific components, and an especially novel aspect of the block-localized orbitals is that diabatic and charge-localized states can be variationally optimized. Several applications have been performed, incluidng an elucidation of the distinction between concerted electron and proton transfer and hydrogen atom transfer mechanisms, singlet fission, and condensed phase simulations.

The impact of this project by developing accurate and novel hybrid QM/MM techniques has been significant, including contributions to the award of the 2013 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, for which it was stated in its Scientific Background that “Important contributions have been given not only by this year’s laureates, but also by many others including J. Gao (the PI of this project), F. Maseras and K. Morokuma, U.C. Sing and P. Kollman, and H. M. Senn and W. Thiel” (http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/2013/advanced-chemistryprize2013.pdf). It is safe to say that hybrid QM/MM approaches have become the method of choice for macromolecular and condensed-phase systems involving bond forming and breaking processes and a change in electronic structure.
